data.text:
SAMUEL HYLAND

In an original recording of â€œCover Me,â€ the harrowing penultimate track to her breakthrough 1995 album Post, BjÃ¶rkâ€™s voice is accompanied by a seemingly-exaggerated echo, a smattering of crackle-pop noises, and numerous irritating-albeit-intermittent squeaks. Right in line with what firebrand esotericism is exuded by the song itself, these sounds were conjured not by in-studio rumblings nor digitized effects, but the bat-infested recesses of a Bahamian caveâ€”upon being given the opportunity to record Post across the ocean from her native London, rather than strictly focus on the metaphysics of her music, Bjorkâ€™s intent was just as hellbent on marrying it all to the physics of the terrestrial. The product is one that walks the same tightrope as its mastermind: there are raging dichotomies between being estranged and understandable, down-to-earth and otherworldly, palatable and eclectic. At the end of the day, yet, when resolved on wax, the conflicts all decay into a twisted, whimsical catharsisâ€”and it is at the heart of this debris that BjÃ¶rk finds her home. â€œIâ€™m going to prove the impossible really exists,â€ she croons in the cave recording, wielding the playful tone of a witch singing a lullaby. Organs, awkward silences and unabridged nature (larger-than-life water drops, more crackle-pop noises, more bat chirps) overtake the remainder of the track; and even in the absence of BjÃ¶rkâ€™s voice, there is the ever-expanding shadow of the absurd.

Though her career was often fronted by a haze of complex paraphernalia that would suggest otherwise, BjÃ¶rk was, beyond just bat caves, preoccupied with the dual extraction of the rudimentary from the intricate, and the intricate from the rudimentary. In an eerily proto-â€œLemonade Mouthâ€ way, the first iteration of her voice on the airwaves was a cover of Tina Charlesâ€™ â€œI Love to Loveâ€ (1976), performed at a school recital when she was 11 years oldâ€”her teachers loved it so much that they sent it to RÃ¡s 1 (at that point, the only radio station in Iceland), which, in broadcasting it, also just so happened to grant an elementary school student the groundwork of a life spent in the public eye. The following year, still 11 years old, BjÃ¶rk released her eponymous debÃºt LP after being signed by the now-defunct FÃ¡lkinn Records as a direct result of her newfound virality. The album was a collection of covers translated into Icelandic; her mother, a hardcore hippie who had adamantly fought against the development of Icelandâ€™s KÃ¡rahnjÃºkar Hydropower Plant, took charge over the extravagant artwork: a deifying portrait of the child, backgrounded by a larger-than-life painting of a warrior on a horse. BjÃ¶rk was signed across the top of the canvas in a kind of pseudo-Arabic drawlâ€”for as much as the songs encased were reimaginings of ones that already exist, the cover alone insinuated the genesis of a new movement. Bursting with the clairvoyant implications of her career writ large, nearly twenty years later, BjÃ¶rk would wail the same love-centric gospel in the same cover-song package: this time to millions of enthralled fans worldwide, and as a cover of Betty Huttonâ€™s 1951 big band ballad â€œItâ€™s Oh So Quiet.â€ â€œThe sky caves in,â€ she sing-shouts in recitation, â€œthe devil cuts loose, you blow, blow, blow, blow, blow your fuse!â€ With every â€œblowâ€ it sounds as if something is indeed blowing up within her, vocal cords surrendering under duress as the impassioned debris escapes her core.

â€œ-rather than please the crowd with what it expected, she seduced starstruck revelers with proof that the impossible really existed, channeling her eclectic craft to dangle the key to it in their faces.â€

The essence of BjÃ¶rkâ€™s approach is typified by such artistic iconoclasm, albeit rooted in a fundamental love for two things: (1) love itself, and (2) everything, both physical and metaphysical, within its reach. It is very easy, and probably not too far off, to imagine the singer as a Disney princess frolicking to and fro through life with the sole beacon in the arc being a set of redeeming, thematic virtues. In her case, these values seem to oscillate by the momentâ€”when she took to the red carpet of 2001â€™s Academy Awards in a wearable swan, for instance, it was her glimmering childlike inventiveness that was on display. (Critics called it â€œone of the dumbest things I have ever seen,â€ said it â€œmade her look like a refugee from the more dog-eared precincts of provincial ballet,â€ and concluded that she â€œshould be put into an asylumâ€). When she recorded vocals in bat-infested caves somewhere in the Bahamas, moreover, it was her unyielding vision for a crossroads between the natural and the unnatural. No matter what, across genres, mediums and messages, the common motif was a lack of reverence for preexisting structures and the audiences conditioned to consume them; rather than please the crowd with what it expected, she seduced starstruck revelers with proof that the impossible really existed, channeling her eclectic craft to dangle the key to it in their faces. And as much as such nature was iconoclastic in essence, its root always circled back to the very thing that first got her voice on the radio: love.

BjÃ¶rk was born in 1965 in Reykjavik, Iceland, a capital city populated with mystical mountainous landscapes, volcanic terrains, and meteorologically extreme summers and winters. At 5 years old, she was enrolled in BarnamÃºsÃ­kskÃ³liâ€”a revered Icelandic music schoolâ€”where she would study classical piano and flute for nearly a decade. The incidental combination of enchanting natural surroundings and a precocious musical practice granted the singer, from youth, a dual reverence for the sonic and the earthly that went on to characterize her output for years to come. On her way to school in the mornings, it is reported that she would often use her time alone to sing to the world, whether that entailed pressing her face against the moss to hum, bellowing with the wind, or whatever intimate antics lay in between. When a Rolling Stone journalist interviewed her in 1995, she recounted using a Post promotional trip to Sweden to sing alone in a local forest. â€œThen I heard some noise, and when I looked around, it was five horses following me,â€ she said. â€œAnd the funny thing was, because I stopped, they stopped as well, they were just standing there pretending they were invisible, with this comical horse expression.â€ No matter how big she was gettingâ€”at the time of the interview, Post had just blown up, and Rolling Stone dubbed her a â€œpunk-turned-divaâ€ who was finally breaking outâ€”she maintained a sort of quasi-fictional, too-good-to-be-true exploratory instinct, forging ambitious and unconventional concoctions in both world and studio.

â€œAnd when the various industries she took part in suggested that she ought to have â€œwishesâ€â€”wealth, power, designer red carpet wear instead of swan dressesâ€”she was consistently too busy frolicking in the garden to remember any of it, let alone indulge.â€

Because BjÃ¶rk was nowhere near as interested in being a child star as her native music industry was in turning her into one, she opted to reject the opportunity to record a follow-up to her 1977 debÃºt, instead undergoing another several years of studying flute and piano at music school. From there she became involved with a number of upstart punk rock bands in the wake of the genreâ€™s rapid spread through Iceland, bearing monikers that translate to â€œCork the Bitchâ€™s Assâ€ and putting forth albums with titles that translate to â€œBite Hard Into Hell.â€ As part of a group called Tappi TÃ­karrass, she graced the cover of Rokk Ã­ ReykjavÃ­k, a 1982 documentary centered on Icelandâ€™s burgeoning alternative music scene. The photo sees her doll-like and half-human, exaggerated round blushes on her cheeks, tilting like an animatronic at Willy Wonkaâ€™s Chocolate Factory whilst clutching the end of a microphone. One year later, she would join a band called Kukl (â€œSorceryâ€ in Icelandic) upon being invited along with an assemblage of other musicians to play the final show of a dissolving radio program; with BjÃ¶rk developing a signature vocal edge seasoned with screeches and shrills, they went on to sign a record deal with the Crass art collective, embarking on an ascent that saw them become the first Icelandic band to play at Denmarkâ€™s Roskilde Festival.

After years spent going from unrealized punk project to unrealized punk project, BjÃ¶rk found her first taste of mainstream success as a member of the Sugarcubes, a bizarre alt-rock faction that arose from the rubble of Kuklâ€™s breakup. They released their first double A-side single â€œEinn molâ€™Ã¡ mannâ€ on her 21st birthday; it was followed by 1987â€™s â€œBirthday,â€ which, upon release, was dubbed â€œsingle of the weekâ€ by Melody Maker. Upon signing a U.S distribution deal with Elektra Records, they recorded Lifeâ€™s Too Good (1988), selling over one million copies worldwide. The album sounds like a stark manifesto of controlled chaosâ€”on â€œColdsweat,â€ the voice of BjÃ¶rk pierces, audaciously, through guitar assemblages that register sonically as jagged glass shards. â€œDeusâ€ sees the singer croon mystically enthralling tunes about a man that â€œdoes not existâ€ (punctuated with asides by the monotone voice of keyboardist Einar Melax: â€œI once met him,â€ he says, rather creepily, at one point. â€œIt really surprised meâ€¦ He put me in a bathtubâ€¦ Made me squeaky cleanâ€¦ Really cleanâ€). â€œDelicious Demonâ€ plays host to BjÃ¶rkâ€™s familiar wail serenading the titular figure, corporeal cracks in her voice giving rise to the suggestion that it is somewhere within her, fighting to get out. The Sugarcubes achieved monumental success globally, performing on Saturday Night Live in 1988 and being crowned the â€œbiggest rock band to emerge from Icelandâ€ in a Rolling Stone biography. â€œThe Sugarcubes make music that is very much like Iceland itself,â€ music critic David Fricke wrote at their height. â€œ-A collision of extremes that can be at once forbidding and mysteriously compelling.â€

Somewhere between BjÃ¶rkâ€™s stint in a million and a half upstart punk rock acts and her rise to prominence with the Sugarcubes, she made her film debÃºt in Nietzchka Keeneâ€™s adaptation of The Juniper Tree, a spin on the original Brothers Grimm fairytale that sees two supernatural siblings vye for safety under the tutelage of an estranged mother. BjÃ¶rk plays the character of Margit, a clairvoyant younger sister who often stares into the abyss with intense eyes, seeming to carry the shadow of the supernatural along with her everywhere she goes. In one haunting scene, she approaches her sibling in a vast expanse of empty, grassy hills, abashedly twirling a flower in her hands. â€œI donâ€™t know if I have any,â€ she says, when asked about her wishes. Her voice comes out in a timid-yet-shrewd silence, the only hint of her shrieking command of the microphone being an eerie echo. â€œYou always say I do. But I never remember anything.â€ As grim as the moment is in context of the film, it is, doubly, yet another inflection of BjÃ¶rkâ€™s strikingly childlike, Disney-princess purity: while the rest of the world worked itself into a consumerist craze as she rose to fame, she opted to remainâ€”whether mentally or physicallyâ€”enveloped in the nakedness of nature, rejecting a slew of conventional commercial structures in the process. And when the various industries she took part in suggested that she ought to have â€œwishesâ€â€”wealth, power, designer red carpet wear instead of swan dressesâ€”she was consistently too busy frolicking in the garden to remember any of it, let alone indulge.

The late 1980s saw BjÃ¶rk go through a series of breakups, the first being a divorce with Sugarcubes bandmate ÃÃ³r Eldon after the birth of their first child, and the second being a split with the band itself, though she was obligated by contract to record a final album with them before she could effectively make an exit. She moved to London, inaugurating her journey as a solo artist with 1993â€™s Debut (the album she recorded at 11 years old isnâ€™t counted as part of her discography, because it is reputed to be juvenilia work). The record was intended to signify the start of something new; and, at this stage in her career, a definitive fresh start was something much-needed: long another stick of indistinct detritus in the heap of Icelandâ€™s fading alt-rock renaissance, her solo act would be tasked with lifting her into her own esteem, beyond her convoluted past and into a more coherent future.

Debut somehow manages to channel both elements at onceâ€”itâ€™s a complex array of eclectic musical approaches, yet it is in this very haze that BjÃ¶rk supernaturally, as always, strings together something that feels like home. On â€œBig Time Sensuality,â€ for instance, exactly one track after she croons somber, acoustic-backed romanticism on â€œLike Someone in Love,â€ she unleashes a bass-heavy, futuristically electro-pop dance number straight from the ballroom of an extraterrestrial coming-of-age film, pulsing with the same exact thematic agenda as the jarringly different track that just faded out. On the albumâ€™s cover, a stark contrast from the last debÃºt project she recorded as an 11 year-old, she is pictured monochrome and stoic, holding her hands up to her mouth with eyes that seem to pierce through the lens. Itâ€™s a mournful image, one that well encapsulates the albumâ€™s pretext: from her departure from both earthly and musical homes, to her divorce from her husband soon after birthing a child, BjÃ¶rk did, indeed, have a great deal to mourn. Still, albeit, Debut exudes a dance-in-the-rain quality omnipresent across the singerâ€™s pneumaâ€”no matter what, it seems, the Icelandic Cinderella always finds her glass slipper.

BjÃ¶rk followed up her (second) solo debÃºt with 1995â€™s Post, in doing so, effectively striking gold with international audiences. Post sees BjÃ¶rk as both relatable and endearingly strange as ever, animating scenic arrangements with her shriek, and wielding her masterfully-honed storytelling ability to craft living, breathing, modern-day fairy tales. Most notable of these fables is likely that of â€œIsobel.â€ Over a busy soundscape of Africanized percussion and eerie, oscillating keys, she paints the titular characterâ€”â€œIsobelâ€ rather than â€œIsabelâ€ per her self-isolating waysâ€”as a woman who completely distances herself from the complexity of the outside world, eventually going on to clash with urbanization before retreating back to her home in the forest. â€œMy name Isobel,â€ BjÃ¶rk croons, voice wavering as if involved in the subjectâ€™s warfare. â€œMarried to myself, My love Isobel, Living by herself.â€ The music video for â€œIsobelâ€ seems to exist in the same barren universe as her character in The Juniper Tree: in a trippy, disorientingly creepy back-and-forth between the singer performing and a group of people watching the story play out in the reflection of a stream, it purports itself as a fever dream, fading out with the haunting image of Bjorkâ€™s estranged head resting at the bottom of a waterfall.

â€œWith Post, BjÃ¶rk set the bionic foundation for one of the most consequential careers in pop history,â€ Pitchfork contributing editor Jenn Pelly wrote in a review of the album. (It received a perfect score). â€œHere is where BjÃ¶rk became a perennial gateway drug, not to one sound but to the unknown, which is to say the future.â€ In order to be a gateway drug, any substance must be able to fulfill two sets of criteria: the first of which being capability to attract, and the second of which being the capability to hook once the attraction is established. It is in this sense that BjÃ¶rk functions as not only an iteration of introductory narcotics, but their quintessential human manifestation: like a living LSD tablet, she invites revelers in with her playful ethos, then hooks them into an inescapable world of colorful catharsis.

Speaking to the aforementioned Rolling Stone journalist, the Brazilian musician Eumir Deodato described BjÃ¶rk as having â€œdeveloped a style and a music that Iâ€™ve never heard anything like in my life.â€ He continued: â€œWhen I heard her material, I freaked out, and I said, â€˜What are you doing? This is crazy, this is so difficult, to propose this kind of style to the people.â€™ But she does, and sheâ€™s successful at it.â€ Listening to BjÃ¶rk is, essentially, embarking on the same psychological step-by-step sequence: first comes doubt, then comes enjoyment, then comes addiction. There is a semi-popular video of Johnny Damon stealing second and third bases in the same play during Game 4 of the 2009 World Series; as he takes off for third, managerial staff in the Yankees dugout shout in disapproval, then once they see that heâ€™s going to make it, they quickly pivot to jubilant encouragement. Oddly, BjÃ¶rkâ€™s artistic oeuvre is strikingly similar to Johnny Damon executing a double stealâ€”when she records her vocals in cave-filled bats, wears swan frocks to red carpet events or takes a break from album promotion to sing to horses in a local forest, the naked eye is seduced into an almost knee-jerk revulsion. But, much like Damon, when it becomes apparent that sheâ€™s somehow still standingâ€”whether howling over sonic glass shards, clutching a microphone like a Wonka-manufactured animatronic, or revitalizing age-old ballads of wartime romanceâ€”the only option left is to cheer her on. The inadvertent cult of personality she enjoyed in the 1990s banked heavily on this quality; it was difficult to understand why or how BjÃ¶rk was doing it, but the fact that she was doing it alone made being an audience member more of an honor than a formality. Pretending you got it could have been just as fun as getting it itself.

â€œ-when you give people a world to live in, even if it isnâ€™t truly theirs for the physical taking, the ever-so-slight possibility exists that they will also make it a hill to die on.â€

Years removed from her initial breakthrough as a solo act, BjÃ¶rk would go on to facilitate a collaboration with the revolutionary New York rap supergroup Wu-Tang Clan, seeking to have group leader RZA contribute beats to her 1997 LP Homogenic. Although that specific endeavor fell through, she was able to reconnect with the faction beyond music on several occasionsâ€”one being at a book signing of hers in New York City. â€œ I turned up,â€ she told Fact in 2017, â€œand seven of the Wu-Tang Clan turned up to, like, protect me! I was signing books for an hour, and they sent some of their team, standing there with me. That was one of my all-time favourite moments: I had been on my own, so when they turned up I felt very protected. It was magic. In my eyes, theyâ€™re punk. We are definitely [similar] â€“ we do things in, like, a ritual way.â€ Even outside the context of any strategized, public-facing body of work, BjÃ¶rkâ€™s innate impulse to see the most disparate universes collide made her a walking crossroads, inadvertently carrying with her a lifetimeâ€™s worth of eclectic scenes. In BjÃ¶rkâ€™s world, a thuggish collective of East Coast rap heroes acts as the army of an Icelandic Cinderella with a history in foreign alt-rockâ€”and not only is it normal, but itâ€™s just the way things ought to be. The only two options are the same ones available for all puzzling snapshots of her career: take part, or walk away.

Unfortunately, with encompassing cults-of-personality like that manufactured by Icelandâ€™s Cinderella, as much as there is a sort of inescapable pull, there is simultaneously the desire to somehow prove for oneself that the fantasy existsâ€”an objective that can go lengths heinously far beyond what original intent lay behind the muse. Over the mid-1990s, Ricardo LÃ³pez, a Georgia pest exterminator, began to grow increasingly enthralled with BjÃ¶rk and her music. He had rapidly deteriorating self-esteem and a reclusive inclination; as he sought more and more to escape reality and cling to whatever fantasies he could get hold of, BjÃ¶rkâ€™s artistry was functionally a perfect nook, complete with illusory visuals, captivating soundscapes and a foundation in mystical nature. A sufferer of Klinefelter syndrome, he was long awkward with girls, dropping out of high school to pursue an artistic career, albeit never going far due to a crippling fear of being rejected. LÃ³pezâ€™s escape of such grim realities was being obsessively infatuated with celebrities, BjÃ¶rk being at the center of his attention: he studied information about her life, paid concerning levels of attention to her career, and directed numerous fan letters to her home address.

Over a number of months, LÃ³pez put together a video diary chronicling both his infatuation with BjÃ¶rk and, consequently, his mental decline. Upon reading in Entertainment Weekly that she had been in a relationship with the British musician Goldie, he grew furious, and quickly began plotting revenge for what he perceived as a stark betrayal (â€œI wasted eight months and she has a fucking lover,â€ he wrote in his physical diary before pivoting to video). To LÃ³pez, as put in one of eleven video diary entries, the intent of his recordings was to chronicle â€œmy life, my art and my plan. Comfort is what I seek in speaking to you â€¦ I am being my own psychologist. You are a camera. I am Ricardo.â€ Growing angrier and angrier with BjÃ¶rk as the installments went onâ€”the extent of his betrayed mindset is perhaps best understood with knowledge that his diary (all 803 pages) contained 168 references to LÃ³pezâ€™s feelings of failure, 34 references to suicide, and 14 references to murderâ€”his plan to â€œpunishâ€ BjÃ¶rk escalated from minor infractions to, finally, full-scale murder: the final plot was to mail a bomb to her home and commit suicide on the same day, the intended end being for the two to reunite in heaven.

In his final video diary entry, titled â€œLast Day â€“ Ricardo LÃ³pez,â€ LÃ³pez sat in front of a sign that read â€œThe best of me. Sept. 12.â€ He nervously prepared to make his visit to the post office, then resumed filming upon returning to his apartment, where, visibly naked, he painted his head red and green. Loud BjÃ¶rk music played in the background as he examined himself in a mirror. Then, as â€œI Remember Youâ€ faded out, he shouted â€œThis is for youâ€ and shot himself in the mouth with a revolver.

Upon discovering LÃ³pezâ€™s corpse several days after the incident, the Broward County Sheriffâ€™s Office got hold of the tapes and effectively intercepted his package before it could reach BjÃ¶rkâ€™s residence. In a statement, BjÃ¶rk said that she was â€œvery distressedâ€ about the incident. She sent flowers and a card to LÃ³pezâ€™s family, and hired security to escort her son, Sinder, to and from school. â€œI make music, but in other terms, you know, people shouldnâ€™t take me too literally and get involved in my personal life,â€ she shakenly told reporters outside her home as the news broke. â€œI make music for people, you see.â€

As much as (1) the extent of carnage initially devised failed, and (2) BjÃ¶rk was in no way at fault, the saga still outlines a harrowing underbelly of creative universes even as colorful and lively as her own: when you give people a world to live in, even if it isnâ€™t truly theirs for the physical taking, the ever-so-slight possibility exists that they will also make it a hill to die on. Not only does BjÃ¶rkâ€™s music radiate eclectic otherworldliness; it invites listeners to indulge in what infinite candylands are advertisedâ€”though it seems common knowledge that the way to go about such mysticism is to return to the real world no matter how long it takes, for some, those universes are too enthralling to abandon. The same life-affirming, nature-embracing music becomes a death trap. And once the substance leaves the control of the source, no matter how innocently or monstrously so, it takes on whatever form the consumer allows it to.

The term â€œStanâ€ began being used to describe obsessive fans following the release of Eminemâ€™s 2000 single of the same name, wherein the titular character murders his immediate family and kills himself upon not getting a response to any of his numerous letters to the musician. Up to present day, the term has come to connote a brand of social media-native superfan, educated on the nitty-gritty details of their artist-of-choiceâ€™s career, and quick to jump to the defenseâ€”often in packsâ€”at the slightest questioning of what legacy they are sworn to protect against attack. Even so, in spite of its more lighthearted ethos than the sagas of BjÃ¶rk and Eminemâ€™s versions, it remains a dangerous extent of artistic reach that brandishes the same exact harrowing deep ends, if not even deeper, as it did decades ago.

Much of this phenomenon is exacerbated by the internet. As social media allows artists themselves to take on informative roles once championed by news publications and tabloids (today, LÃ³pez would likely have found out about BjÃ¶rkâ€™s relationship on Twitter and not Entertainment Weekly), the presence and silence of a celebrity figure alike may each give way to conversations all-but-guaranteed to outlast original intent. Perhaps this is more obviously true for the silence: when big musicians like Kanye West and Frank Ocean go quiet for longer than usual, the narrative ritually eclipses them, with increasingly wild theories serving as footprints of increasingly desperate fanbases. Even for the opposite approach, notorious social media loudmouths like Nicki Minaj and Soulja Boy inadvertently, with their passion, rile up fans to a point where whatever is given them, even if not a direct call to action, is taken and run away with.

â€œ-she didnâ€™t need a red carpet to possess people, and before the internet could carry her message for her, it was her output alone that both brought people into her world, and made it a graveyard for those who couldnâ€™t get out.â€

In Minajâ€™s case, for instance, upon catching wind of a critical tweet from writer Wanna Thompson that made a point of her age, she retaliated in a series of scathing direct messages that were soon made public. â€œWhen ya ugly ass was 24 u were pushing 30?â€ one of the DMs read. â€œIâ€™m 34. Iâ€™m touching 40? Lol. And what does that have to do with my music? Eat a dick u hating ass hoe.â€ Devoted Minaj fans pounced on the matter once it reached their Twitter feeds. â€œMs. Thompson said she has received thousands of vicious, derogatory missives across Twitter, Instagram, Facebook, email and even her personal cellphone, calling her every variation of stupid and ugly, or worse,â€ the New York Times reported in 2018. â€œSome of the anonymous horde included pictures Ms. Thompson once posted on Instagram of her 4-year-old daughter, while others told her to kill herself. Ms. Thompson also lost her internship at an entertainment blog in the chaotic days that followed, and she is now considering seeing a therapist.â€

The loudest fans on the internet, whether their respective artists are outspoken chatterboxes or silent personages, are fueled by creative ephemera that is gripping enough to be passionately defendedâ€”when the silent artist neglects to speak for themself, the captivated audience, mobilized by the music, feels responsible to argue on their behalf; all the same, when the outspoken artist invokes diversity of opinion with their ever-running mouth, the audience, just as captivated and emboldened by the music, feels the need to jump to the defense of what first showed them the light. BjÃ¶rk exists in a strange in-between, in that when sheâ€™s talkative, it isnâ€™t in a self-righteous sense, and when sheâ€™s not talking, it isnâ€™t in the off-the-grid context of a Kanye West or Frank Ocean. Her too-good-to-be-true eternal childhood transcends the existent structures of social media and its marriage to modern-day artistry, and even without a fully-realized internet to inflame the obsession she channeled, it allowed an extreme case like that of LÃ³pez to remain possible.

When, every few years or so, social media holds contentious debates on whether (insert 20th Century artist here)â€™s fanbase was bigger than that of (insert 21st Century artist here), videos often circulate of young women fainting at the sight of Michael Jackson, Madonna being greeted by camera flashes and raucous mobs, or Yasiin Bey freestyling at the center of a captivated swarm in New York City. Though similar images are not the first to come to mind when BjÃ¶rk is brought up, with an especial consideration of what impact she had on people like LÃ³pez, it is beyond necessary to include her in such a pantheon: she didnâ€™t need a red carpet to possess people, and before the internet could carry her message for her, it was her output alone that both brought people into her world, and made it a graveyard for those who couldnâ€™t get out.

As of right now, at 53 years of age, BjÃ¶rk hasnâ€™t lost her place, nor her credit, in the international cultural canon. â€œTwenty-five years later,â€ Pelly wrote in the aforementioned Post review, â€œyou donâ€™t need to scroll far through BjÃ¶rkâ€™s Instagram feed to find the most audacious young popular artists alive, the likes of Arca and RosalÃ­a, heeding that call, crowning her â€˜queen.â€™â€ Itâ€™s a heartwarming prospect, one that insinuates a passing of the torch to young cultural iconoclasts who will not only disrupt culture in line with BjÃ¶rkâ€™s own rebellion, but hijack it en route to a brand new, compelling tomorrow. At the same time, though, the same prospect is one that begs a question faced by â€œweirdâ€ artists both preceding and succeeding the Icelandic punk-surrealist: what determines who is allowed to stand the test of time, and who isnâ€™t? BjÃ¶rk was not the first, and by all measures, certainly will not be the last, cultural provocateur who finds a playground in going against the grain. Weâ€™ve heard the names of many from past and present alike: Dean Blunt, Lou Reed, George Clinton, et cetera. But for the few that have broken surface tension and graced our radars, heaps and heaps of similar eccentricity remain at the ocean floorâ€”why donâ€™t all see the top?

It isnâ€™t that such outputs lack the same transcendence exhibited in discographies like BjÃ¶rkâ€™s own. â€œItâ€™s so healing-sounding, his music,â€ the musician Vinyl Williams said of Iasosâ€”a pioneer of the â€œnew ageâ€ genreâ€”in a Zoom interview last year. â€œ(But) the thing is that Iasos would not be played in public, generally.
